Answer: Jaws.After the initial attack then the movie would follow as it does for the investigation and the reporting which tries to cover it up as a "boating accident". However after the scene where a beach full of people witness the death of Alex Kintner then smartphones and social media would have #AmityShark or #AmityKidEatenByShark? trending and footage of the blood in the water going viral. People would avoid the beach and a national outcry would result in funds coming in for a professional operation conducted to hunt and kill the territorial shark with no need for the Three Men in a Boat third aJaws.After the initial attack then the movie would follow as it does for the investigation and the reporting which tries to cover it up as a "boating accident". However after the scene where a beach full of people witness the death of Alex Kintner then smartphones and social media would have #AmityShark or #AmityKidEatenByShark? trending and footage of the blood in the water going viral. People would avoid the beach and a national outcry would result in funds coming in for a professional operation conducted to hunt and kill the territorial shark with no need for the Three Men in a Boat third act which would be deemed too amateurish.

Answer: This is more public knowledge involving technology, but much of the plot of Lethal Weapon 3 is based on inaccurate news reporting of teflon coated bullets being armor defeating. I think the guy even shoots through the bucket or blade of some industrial power equipment to kill someone with one at the end.But yeah, it seems real odd watching the movie now, considering that it's been widely discredited, but was, at one point, such a believable news story that a blockbuster action film was built around it.

Answer: You'll need to define "meaningful technology." It would seem to me that meaningful technology predates Homo sapiens sapiens. Our not-quite-human ancestors were already using fire, something no other species (well, genus anyway) has ever done, and we were making unprecedented use of stone tools. Throw in use of perishable materials like fibers, leather, and wood to make tools and garments, and we were able to spread out from Africa and the Middle East to colonizeYou'll need to define "meaningful technology." It would seem to me that meaningful technology predates Homo sapiens sapiens. Our not-quite-human ancestors were already using fire, something no other species (well, genus anyway) has ever done, and we were making unprecedented use of stone tools. Throw in use of perishable materials like fibers, leather, and wood to make tools and garments, and we were able to spread out from Africa and the Middle East to colonize

Answer: Most of it, honestly.But one that I just keep coming back to is nanotechnology. Specifically all the different super-capable robots that only show up under microscopes.People always sell them as being capable of doing all these astonishing things - burrowing into rock to extract metals, forming into a shape shifting colony organism that still just chooses to look like Robert Patrick 95% of the time, wiping out the world by turning it into gray goo, etc.But there are three things they almost never talk about:Most of it, honestly.But one that I just keep coming back to is nanotechnology. Specifically all the different super-capable robots that only show up under microscopes.People always sell them as being capable of doing all these astonishing things - burrowing into rock to extract metals, forming into a shape shifting colony organism that still just chooses to look like Robert Patrick 95% of the time, wiping out the world by turning it into gray goo, etc.But there are three things they almost never talk about:The answers to these questions pretty much guarantee you could never actually build the kind of nanomachines we see in science fiction. But, hey, they're still fun!

Answer: Have you ever seen one of these monsters?I think everyone will recognize a Bugatti these days. The keen of eye among you might peg it to be Bolide.It isn’t street-legal and was built purely for track fun. But the car itself isn’t the sci-fi bit; though it is the pinacle of combustion engine vehicles.No… The sci-fi tech is what’s happening under the hood. Specifically near the wheels. It has two of the largest, most complex titanium 3D printed parts in the world.The first one are the brakes calipers.It’s an eight-piston monoblock. Some of the lightest, most powerful brakes on the planet. They aHave you ever seen one of these monsters?I think everyone will recognize a Bugatti these days. The keen of eye among you might peg it to be Bolide.It isn’t street-legal and was built purely for track fun. But the car itself isn’t the sci-fi bit; though it is the pinacle of combustion engine vehicles.No… The sci-fi tech is what’s happening under the hood. Specifically near the wheels. It has two of the largest, most complex titanium 3D printed parts in the world.The first one are the brakes calipers.It’s an eight-piston monoblock. Some of the lightest, most powerful brakes on the planet. They are also the largest car brakes in the world.The drive shaft is printed as well. It dropped the weight by 1,5kg and increased possible operating temperature. Dropping rotating mass increased the engine’s output.The rear wing weighs 600 grams and is also 3D printed from titanium and carbon fibre.3D printing itself isn’t that incredible to me. But 3D printing titanium at this level is absolutely incredible. I have literally no idea how that works to such a degree of reliability a company like Bugatti uses it. And I have education in engineering…

Answer: Powered exoskeletons…“I am ze Rhino!”Sure, powered exoskeletons look pretty damn cool. I won’t argue there. And yeah, they’re a hell of a lot better than fighting somebody without one.But, here’s the thing about powered exoskeletons: the person within the exoskeleton limits the exoskeleton’s capabilities. Suddenly, the exoskeleton has to account for a person’s heat tolerance, the types of forces a person can withstand, a person’s range of motion… It’s a mess.Wouldn’t it just be smarter to design a robot instead of an exoskeleton, and man it remotely? Not only would you be able to build a far sPowered exoskeletons…“I am ze Rhino!”Sure, powered exoskeletons look pretty damn cool. I won’t argue there. And yeah, they’re a hell of a lot better than fighting somebody without one.But, here’s the thing about powered exoskeletons: the person within the exoskeleton limits the exoskeleton’s capabilities. Suddenly, the exoskeleton has to account for a person’s heat tolerance, the types of forces a person can withstand, a person’s range of motion… It’s a mess.Wouldn’t it just be smarter to design a robot instead of an exoskeleton, and man it remotely? Not only would you be able to build a far stronger machine — you don’t have to account for human limitations — but you’ll also be able to keep its operatorThere’s a reason why the U.S military invests tons of money into drones and robots, and barely anything into powered exoskeletons.Sorry Tony Stark: your Iron Man suit makes no goddamn sense.
